children.value: Turns out it's advisable to get medical care to grow and birth a baby. I had 14 pre-baby checkups with my OB for baby #1 (and 2 post-baby visits), and the same for baby #2. Then there are dozens of blood/urine tests, a few ultrasounds, and a several day (if you're lucky) stay at the hospital.
Then, once the baby is born, you have well visits - we had 7 well visits (typically covered 100% by insurance) and one sick visit in baby's first year.
That stuff costs $$. How much? Due to the complicated nature of insurance, it's really quite hard to estimate, even from one uncomplicated pregnancy to the next.
Overall, I spent money in these categories:
Obviously, this varies a lot across regions, circumstances (C-section? Epidural? Twins?), and health insurances, so this is just a snapshot of what

paid for "having the baby", as well as baby's medical needs in his first year. Note that this doesn't include over the counter items like Tylenol and saline spray, but would include prescription drugs if necessary.

Our deductible for baby #1 was $1,350 (individual) and $2,700 (family, once baby came), and for baby #2 it was $1,400 (individual) and $2,800 (family, once baby came). We pay 10% of our costs over the deductible, up to an out-of-pocket max of $2,800/$5,600 - assuming in-network. Note that baby #1 was on my husband's insurance in the year that baby #2 came, so both pregnancies occurred on an individual plan and converted to family once baby came for the rest of the year.
Ensuring you give your baby a healthy environment to grow in means avoiding some foods, but also popping some daily vitamins. MayoClinic has a

You're supposed to start taking these if you're trying to conceive, due to the importance of folic acid early in pregnancy. And prenatal vitamins = postnatal vitamins if you're breastfeeding (I did, for >1 year). I settled on these
I was anemic later in my pregnancy (this is fairly common), even though my prenatal vitamin contained iron. My OB recommended these
ones to reduce side effects, since there are already plenty of unpleasant side effects during pregnancy anyway.
Breastfed babies don't typically get enough Vitamin D, so supplementation is recommended. I frequently forgot to give some to the baby, so I supplemented my own diet as well.

Most of the expenses of having a baby come from seeing doctors and performing tests that they order, as well as care in the hospital. I gave birth in a hospital - obviously this would differ some with a home birth. These expenses can be divided into 2 categories:
I have medical bills from two babies, born 2 years apart in Aug 2019 and Aug 2021. The cost after insurance discounts diffs a little bit (~$15,800 vs. ~$13,000), as did our cost: $1,640 vs. $3,811.
Baby has a heartbeat! But looks like a gummy bear...
Pap smear, CBC, antibody tests, blood typing, etc.
So fun to see baby moving around and actually looking like a baby
We switched OB practices mid-pregnancy, so this is the cost of the doctor visits, but not delivery.
We switched OB practices mid-pregnancy, so this is the cost of the doctor visits from Jun-Aug, but not delivery.
We had already hit our OOP max due to cell-free fetal DNA test bill (see
Cost of OB services during delivery.
Maybe a pap smear at my 6 week post-partum appointment?

properties.ariaLabel: cell free fetal dna tests permalink

children.value: There is a blood test that is often done in the late 1st trimester/early 2nd trimester, called a

. It screens for certain chromosomal abnormalities in the baby, like Down's syndrome, trisomy 13, and trisomy 18 (and the baby's sex, since they're in there looking at the genes anyway). We had two different OBs, who both recommended getting the (optional) test, even though neither pregnancy was high risk. They stated it would help give the proper care/expectations if anything was abnormal, but said we could opt-out if we wanted.

Given that it's an optional, potentially expensive test, we tried to weigh the cost with the benefits of having the additional information. Naturally, I reached out to my insurance company, who said that it might be covered, but that they would need the doctor's office to call and answer a few questions to confirm. We asked the doctor's office to do so, but they said they don't do that for this test, and said something like "90+% of people don't ever see a bill, and the ones that do pay <$200, and if yours is more, call this represenative and they'll reduce it for you".

This was an incredibly dissatisfying answer. Is it covered, or not? How much will it cost? Is it in or out of network? This should be completely answerable - the test is straightforward (blood draw and a standard panel of tests). There aren't variables like "well, when we tried to repair your heart 3 other things went wrong and we had to give you some extra blood and anesthesia and you needed to spend 3 extra days in the hospital so that costs more". None of that uncertainty applies here, and this is a test being recommended to hundreds of thousands of pregnant women each year.

It's not that we don't mind paying for the test - a small monetary trade-off for better care for our baby and peace of mind are certainly worthwhile. We decided to do the test, because the financial burden on our family if it went south was manageable. This is a luxury for us, but not all families. Still - being stuck with an unexpected $3,000 bill is not something we wished for. If we knew ahead of time that the test would be $3,000, we would not have done it.
The test was performed in Feb 2019. Our HSA account auto-populated some claims:

I don't ever remember seeing an official explanation of benefits from the insurance company - I'm usually very meticulous about this. The baby came in Aug 2019, and we received bills for the delivery and OB care, but nothing for the cell-free fetal DNA test 6 months prior. We thought, "great, we're part of the 90%".
, MORE THAN 2.5 YEARS after the test was performed, we received a bill in the mail from Progenity. It said "there is a balance due in the amount of $2,742.42", please go to this website to pay it.

Like all medical bills, it does not have a due date (WHY??? Bills should have due dates...) After logging in, it states that the insurance company made an adjustment and payment in March 2019 (a reasonable time to pay for a Feb 2019 bill), and that the remainder of ~$2,700 is now due (Oct 2021).
In my mom's group on Facebook, there is a thread with 6+ other women who got bills like this. Progenity also agreed to pay a
to Medicaid and the VA due to fradulent billing codes and illegal kikcbacks to physicians, so there's definitely something fishy going on here.

I emailed my OBGYN who ordered the test, and they left me a voicemail to the effect of "don't worry about that bill; you don't have to pay it; they won't send it to collections". WHAT?!?!? I can't just ignore a $2,700 bill, can I? How is this a normal thing.

An interesting side-effect is that, due to this bill, the insurance company assumed I was paying a large amount of out-of-network out of pocket costs (~$2,700), and any future in-network care before my plan changed from an individual plan to a family plan (on baby's birthday) was completely free to me. The 10% coinsurance cost to me of these bills would have been $1,256, so doing this test "saved" a chunk of $$, although it's unclear how much of the Progenity bill will actually need to be paid.
Antibody tests, etc. Some of these tests were covered as 100% preventative care, and others weren't.
Hit our deductible here, so things are going to 10% instead of 100%.
(negative test indicates low probability of going into labor in the next 2 weeks). We did this for peace of mind on a trip into the mountains.

properties.ariaLabel: comparisons between the two pregnancies permalink

children.value: Baby 1 and Baby 2 came almost exactly 2 years apart. A few interesting things:

Baby 1 had a higher total cost, likely due to a longer stay at the hospital (3 vs. 2 days) and an epidural (baby #2 came so fast there wasn't time). We paid less though. because we hit our OOP max early due to the large Progenity bill, and baby #1 came after midnight, so technically the day after we arrived at the hospital, resulting in all of mom's costs being billed on the date we checked into the hospital at the free "you already met your OOP max and you're not on a family plan yet".

The cost of OBGYN prenatal care & delivery (after insurance discounts) was $3,475 with baby #1, and $3,150 with baby #2. Apparently not a lot of inflation there? An interesting billing note was the gestational diabetes blood test, which cost ~$10 after insurance discount, but was billed at $275 for baby #1, and $59 for baby #2.
Baby's first year comes with lots of check-ups to ensure baby is developing properly, plus a bunch of vaccinations. These are all considered preventative care, covered by our insurance at 100%.
Baby #2's well visits and vaccinations were also completely covered ($0 cost for us). Over 2 years, the cost to insurance for an office visit rose from $140 to ~$145 (~3.5% increase).

We are fortunate to have very good insurance. My employer covered my healthcare premiums while I was on maternity leave, so the first 4 months of having baby covered were free. For the remaining 8 months of baby #1's first year of life, we upgraded my husband's individual coverage to a family plan for an additional
$130/month in premiums, for a total cost of $1,040.
We took 2 classes at our hospital to help us prepare to be new parents. We're glad we took them for baby #1, but skipped them for baby #2.

for baby #1, $4.50 for baby #2. I managed to wait to use them until after I felt nauseous/hormonal enough to think I was pregnant (instead of taking them early in hopes of a positive test); otherwise, we may have gone through a few more packs.
My OB recommended wearing these while flying in my 2nd trimester and beyond. I vaguely recall they should reduce the risk of blood clots and also decrease uncomfortable swelling.
